Award.AwardTitle: Ocean Carbon and Biogeochemistry Program Ocean Acidification Principal Investigators' Meeting, March 22-24 2011
Award.AbstractNarration: This award will partially support a three-day meeting of U.S. principal investigators funded to conduct ocean acidification research. It is designed to build capacity within the ocean acidification research community, to advance scientific research on ocean acidification as efficiently as possible, and to clarify the scientific frontiers within ocean acidification research. The invitees include approximately 20% early-career scientists and 30% women. The specific goals of the meeting are (1) Strengthen scientific collaborations and minimize duplication of efforts; (2) Build capacity for improving ocean acidification research; (3) Identify short- and long-term research goals; (4) Promote effective data management; (5) Enhance communication with the public; and (6) Solicit feedback from the scientific community to guide future activities. The meeting includes a mix of plenary talks reviewing state-of-the-art knowledge on 5 themes of ocean acidification research; synthesis presentations and panel discussions considering how present research efforts fit together; breakout sessions discussing overarching challenges in ocean acidification research; poster sessions; and plenary discussions concerning future directions in ocean acidification research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant partially funded the first national meeting for U.S. investigators funded to conduct ocean acidification (OA) research, which took place March 22-24, 2011 and was organized by the U.S. Ocean Carbon and Biogeochemistry Program (OCB; www.us-ocb.org).

Intellectual merit:This meeting, the first of its kind, gathered academic and Federal OA researchers representing almost all the current OA-related research projects supported by federal entities (NSF, NASA, NOAA, USGS, EPA, Naval Postgraduate School). The meeting organizers sought to build capacity within the OA research community, advance scientific research on OA as efficiently as possible, and clarify the scientific frontiers within OA research. Prior to this, OA research projects were being conducted with very little cross-communication among researchers, institutions, or agencies, and the risk of duplicating efforts was high.

Broader impacts: The meeting was designed to fulfill 6 goals for the entire U.S. OA research community: strengthen the scientific collaborations in the U.S. ocean acidification research community and minimize duplication of efforts; bring new scientists into the ocean acidification research community (i.e., build capacity); identify short and long term research goals; promote management of data that will help researchers make the most of data from completed studies; enhance communication with the public; and solicit feedback from the scientific community concerning how OCB, the meeting organizer, can support future ocean acidification activities.

Meeting outcomes: All of the materials generated as part of the meeting (abstract booklet, participants' talk slides, videos of talks, project report) are freely available at the meeting website: www.whoi.edu/workshops/OAPI2011. After the meeting, the workshop organizers circulated a short survey to participants to gauge whether our goals had been met. Most meeting participants agreed that the 6 meeting goals were largely fulfilled. Participants also provided suggestions about improving breakout group productivity in the future, activities to include in future meetings, and the usefulness of this particular meeting and its format. All of these complete responses and summaries of workshop breakout discussions, are available in the meeting report, which is freely downloadable as a PDF document from the meeting website, or directly from this link: https://www.whoi.edu/fileserver.do?id=90204&pt=2&p=107329.
